displayed_text: Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo. Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go.

Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Let’s put that there. Okay. Any other bumps or lumps that you’ve noted? Any rashes, skin changes? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: And have you been able to-? Any of these things come out to you? Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. So your iron stuff isn’t really helping, but, huh, your kidney test, liver tests, your potassium is on the low side so you take your supplement. You probably often forget one of them, one of them probably, I bet. Doctor: It’s hard to remember that second one. Blood sugar’s okay. One of your bone tests is still high, but not as high as it was last time. That doesn’t mean we’re going to do anything different. But, huh, and then your liver tests, kidney tests are normal. Huh, your testosterone says you have no testosterone. So the medicines we’ve been giving you are doing their job. Then your PSA has changed. Huh, it was twenty three months ago, twenty-eight when I saw you four weeks ago, and now it’s thirty-nine. Let’s see what we have for scans. I’ll look at your brain. Your brain looks fine. Now to this MRI. Really they don’t talk much about your bones. That’s good. Huh, let’s see. Your bone scan. Huh, did we have that last time as well? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual.

Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving?

Patient: Right, exactly right. Doctor: Awesome. Sounds like a plan. Uh as soon as we locate the right one you’ll be the first to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um I think M______ wanted to just say hi. Stick her head in here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we all eyeball you and then (sound MD makes noise for effect) Patient: Yeah so she can see my hair style. Patient: I- You know I was getting so little in the back I just decided… Doctor: Aww. Patient: I’m just gonna shave it all off. Doctor: Did you do that? Really? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: But what she’s talkin’ about – Doctor: Is a treatment. Family Member: Exactly. As long as you – ‘cuz my sister’s father deals with the prostate. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Family Member: He gets chemotherapy. Okay? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or – Patient: Well, doc, you know --

Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right?

Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah.

Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Huh, we might make the decision when you’re back in a month, huh, and then we can go from there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you need a refill on your morphine? Or are you good? Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine. Doctor: Okay. And you’ve been emailing me? Who’s been writing the pain people? Who’s been doing that for you? Patient: What? Doctor: When you need a refill. Patient: Huh, I call R___. Doctor: Okay. But then they need a doctor to sign it. Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need

Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Well it is doing everything it’s supposed to do because if you look at your lymph node, remember the bones hardly ever change. Patient: Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down.

Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do? Doctor: Yeah, so that; we have talked about that. You know your kidney function has gotten better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know so that is one of the key parts about you being eligible, that if your kidney function was too high, makes it difficult for us to use chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Chemotherapy with your numbers today, you could certainly go ahead and start moving forward with that and picking a date. You know for you to do the clinical trial then we do have to have you; D___ even kept an eye on you and let me know that you were in the hospital. You know we’ve got all kinds of I think Dr._____ one note said that Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Right. Doctor: That sort of again goes more with arthritis. Okay. Family Member: Okay so if he doesn’t want to do surgery what about laser surgery? I mean that’s not opening it up. Is that another… Doctor: Right yeah that is absolutely an option. Family Member: …viable option? Doctor: And I would ask the neurosurgeon about it. Frankly if laser is an option for this location, for that… Family Member: Right. Doctor: Exact lesion things like that because I really don’t know exactly which lesions would be good for that. Definitely ask about there is a procedure called kyphoplasty which can stabilize the spine. Patient: Hypo? Doctor: Kypho, kypho. K-Y-P-H-O and you know that’s something also to uh explore with neurosurgery. Okay? So um… Patient: Yeah I I’m not too anxious to have them go in there if it’s not gonna help me. Because I can live the way I am. Doctor: Yeah. I mean I wouldn’t have surgery if it’s not – if it’s unlikely to help for sure…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more
Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Family Member: Just you? Oh wow. Doctor: And, if you want to know more, I mean, we can also have you, an appointment with one of our genetic counselors. Patient: Well, you, you gave me a card with your other e-mail. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Not – so I still have that. Doctor: Yeah, so if anybody, you know, has questions about it and wants more information. You know, I’m not a genetic counselor, but I can at least tell them what I just told you Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And kind of try to, and then I’m going to find out probably today or tomorrow what this color test --- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I don’t get anything from this test. It’s just an easy one to do. Family Member: Yeah, you know what MTHFR is? Do you know is that related to this? Because our daughter has that. Doctor: I don’t know what that means.

Family Member: And I had to go in. Dr. F___ was over at the C___’s Hospital. I went in with Dr. S____. Doctor: You did not tell me she had a mini-stroke. Family Member: They put a PFO closure and found a hole in my heart. Doctor: Why didn’t you tell me? Oh, gosh. Family Member: Yeah. I have a closure piece in there. Doctor: You okay now? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: She looks great. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: From our first days of meeting. Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?
